Yarmuth alone in defense Obama on immigration

Yarmuth alone in defense Obama on immigration

Politics

James R. Carroll, The Courier-Journal 2:55 p.m. EST November 21, 2014

Immigration activists in front of the White House.(Photo: USA TODAY)

Tags

  • Mitch McConnell
  • Rand Paul
  • John Yarmuth
  • Dan Coats
  • Joe Donnelly
5 CONNECT 4 TWEETLINKEDIN 4 COMMENTEMAILMORE

WASHINGTON - Most Kentucky and Indiana area members of Congress are vehemently opposed to President Barack Obama's plans to protect undocumented immigrants from deportations, saying it defies what the public wants and exceeds his legal authority.

In the hours before and after Obama's Thursday night address on immigration to the nation, the predominantly Republican lawmakers objected to the president's effort to do through executive action what he could not achieve through legislation.

And on Friday, House Republicans filed the first of what may be multiple legal challenges to Obama's actions.

Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who will become majority leader in January, tore into the president's move on Thursday.

"Just as the 'Affordable Care Act' had little to do with making health care more affordable, slapping the term 'immigration reform' on something doesn't mean it's actually immigration reform," McConnell said in Senate floor remarks.

RELATED: Obama declares "lawful action" to protect immigrants

FULL TEXT: Obama's address to the nation on immigration

"And just as with Obamacare, the action the president is proposing isn't about solutions," he said. "It isn't about compassion. It seems to be about what a political party thinks would make for good politics."

Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., told Fox News that what the president was trying to do on immigration was against "the fundamental separation of powers we have in this country."

President Obama announced a historic immigration reform to protect 5 million undocumented immigrants from deportation. USA TODAY's Alan Gomez dissects what this means for immigrants, Republicans, and the 2016 presidential election.

"He has absolutely no right through executive order to rewrite immigration law," Paul said. "History will treat him unkindly on this if he thinks he can become king."

Sen. Dan Coats, R-Ind., said the president's role "is to faithfully execute the law, not alter or ignore it as he sees fit."

"If the president changes existing immigration law via executive order, he will exceed his Constitutional authority and ignore the wishes of the American people," the senator said in a statement.

Even Indiana Sen. Joe Donnelly, a Democrat, would not back what the president is doing.

"I am as frustrated as anyone that Congress is not doing its job, but the president shouldn't make such significant policy changes on his own," he said in a statement.

But Rep. John Yarmuth, D-3rd District, was the lone defender of the president among his area congressional colleagues.

Obama's decision is going to put pressure on congressional Republicans to counter with their own reforms, Yarmuth said in an interview with The Courier-Journal.

However, the Louisville Democrat said, political divisions within the Republican Party make such a response doubtful.

"They know this will put the onus back on them," Yarmuth said of the GOP. "That's why (the Republicans) make such a big deal out of executive action. It's going to be on them now."

Rep. Hal Rogers, R-5th District, said Congress must fight Obama through the enactment of legislation, although cutting off funds to the agency that would implement the president's plan is technically not feasible.

"With this new proposal, the president has once again demonstrated his willingness to act unilaterally - against the spirit of our Constitution, against the law of Congress, and against the will of the American people - to make misguided, unwarranted changes to our immigration laws," Rogers said in a statement.

"Incredibly disheartening" and "legally questionable" is how Rep. Brett Guthrie, R-2nd District, described Obama's plan.

"The American people spoke earlier this month and elected a new Congress, whose responsibility it is to update and alter our nation's laws," Guthrie said in the statement. "The president's repeated 'go it alone' attitude flies in the face of the will of the American people."

Obama's directive is "a direct affront" to the voters, Rep. Ed Whitfield, R-1st District, said in a statement, adding that the administration is not focusing on the primary issue of border security.

"Unless this president changes his approach to addressing our country's immigration problems, the situation at our borders will only get worse," the lawmaker said.

Rep. Andy Barr, R-6th District, tweeted to his followers after his floor remarks that "it's time for real reform, not unilateral action."

Rep. Todd Young, R-9th District, Indiana, tweeted the results of an NBC News poll that found 48 percent of Americans opposed unilateral action by the president.
